thread.title: Neville, Bastrop meet in pivotal district game
thread.title_full: Neville, Bastrop meet in pivotal district game

title: Neville, Bastrop meet in pivotal district game
text:
Neville, Bastrop meet in pivotal district game Brett Hudson , bhudson@thenewsstar.com 8:21 a.m. CDT October 9, 2015 Neville enters this week’s game against Bastrop off of a bye week. (Photo: Brett Hudson/The News-Star) 4 CONNECT 3 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Neville and Bastrop are playing for a lot more than the 10 power points at stake. 
The Tigers and the Rams meet each other Friday night in a battle of top 10 teams in the state – No. 1 Neville and No. 7 Bastrop last week, before Bastrop’s win over Richwood – with the driver’s set in District 2-4A for the taking. 
“I think Bastrop can be one of the top 4A teams that has the opportunity to advance in the playoffs. They're that type of team, they have that type of skill and they're playing well enough to do that,” Neville head coach Mickey McCarty said. “We feel like we can improve enough to be that kind of team, as well, if we continue to do the things we need to do to improve. 
“It's a big game for both teams, heading into the second half of the season here. It should be a great game, it's an exciting atmosphere, it's a great matchup and have some hype around it.” 
Both teams bring explosive offenses to the table. Neville has scored 40 or more points in three of its four games this year, topping 50 in two of those games. Bastrop is equally dangerous, averaging 25 points a game and, like Neville, has scored over 40 points three times and over 50 points twice. The Rams even scored 56 points in their only loss of the season in the debut against Parkway. BLOG: NELA Individual Stats Leaders, Week 6 
“They've got a lot of playmakers,” Neville defensive coordinator Benjy Lewis said. “If they did one thing well, it'd be a lot easier, but when you look at it they have multiple running back that do things well, they have the receivers and they have a mobile quarterback, so it presents problems on a lot of fronts for us.” 
The Rams’ quarterback-wide receiver duo of Jerry Powell and Isaiah Graham – Graham plans to announce his college football program of choice later this month from Arkansas, Tennessee, South Carolina, TCU and Miami – attracts the most attention, but Neville thinks it’s the threats around them that make the Rams tough to defend. 
“They're very talented at all skill positions. All of them really sting you from any place on the field,” McCarty said. “They have great speed, as most Bastrop teams have. 
“(Powell) can throw it over the top of the defense with nice touch and he can throw in the quick game with nice accuracy. He's one of those guys where if you try to flush him out of the pocket, he can certainly burn you from there.” Ben Nola fuels Neville defense sans stats 
The Bastrop defense is no pushover, either, allowing just seven points in the last two games and less than 14 per game in the last four. 
“(Bastrop) Coach (Brad) Bradshaw has always done a good job defensively,” McCarty said. “Last week they pitched a shutout, I know they're very proud of that. They always play physical defense, so we have to match that physicality.”
